words.definition: implied or understood without being stated directly
sentences: There was a tacit agreement between them.
His tacit approval encouraged the team.

words.definition: reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
sentences: The taciturn man rarely spoke at meetings.
She became taciturn after the argument.

words.definition: only slightly connected or relevant to the main topic
sentences: His comments were tangential to the discussion.
The tangential remark confused the audience.

words.definition: to tease or torment by presenting something desirable but keeping it out of reach
sentences: The aroma of fresh bread tantalized the hungry children.
She tantalized him with hints about the surprise.

words.definition: too long, slow, or dull; tiresome or monotonous
sentences: The tedious lecture put everyone to sleep.
Filing paperwork is a tedious task.

words.definition: excessive confidence or boldness; audacity
sentences: He had the temerity to challenge the expert.
Her temerity in negotiations surprised everyone.

words.definition: moderation or self-restraint, especially in drinking alcohol
sentences: The movement promoted temperance and healthy living.
He practiced temperance in all aspects of life.

words.definition: characterized by strong and turbulent emotions or actions
sentences: Their tempestuous relationship was full of drama.
The tempestuous weather delayed our flight.

words.definition: able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection
sentences: Her position was no longer tenable after the scandal.
The theory seemed tenable with the new evidence.

words.definition: holding firmly to something; persistent and determined
sentences: The tenacious athlete never gave up.
She was tenacious in pursuing her goals.

words.definition: uncertain or hesitant; not fully worked out or developed
sentences: We made a tentative plan for the weekend.
His tentative steps showed his nervousness.

words.definition: very weak or slight; insubstantial
sentences: The connection between the events was tenuous.
His grip on reality became tenuous.

words.definition: using few words; abrupt or curt
sentences: His terse reply ended the conversation.
The memo was terse and to the point.

words.definition: concerned with or involving theory rather than practical application
sentences: The idea is only theoretical at this point.
She studied theoretical physics in college.

words.definition: to prevent someone from accomplishing something
sentences: The police thwarted the robbery attempt.
Bad weather thwarted our hiking plans.

words.definition: showing or suffering from nervousness or fear
sentences: The timorous child hid behind her mother.
He gave a timorous knock on the door.

words.definition: a long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
sentences: The coach launched into a tirade after the loss.
Her tirade lasted for twenty minutes.

words.definition: a person who flatters others for personal gain
sentences: The toady agreed with everything the boss said.
Nobody trusted the office toady.

words.definition: mentally or physically inactive; sluggish
sentences: The heat made everyone feel torpid.
The torpid bear slept through winter.

words.definition: full of twists and turns; excessively complicated
sentences: The tortuous mountain road was dangerous.
His tortuous explanation confused everyone.

words.definition: easy to control or influence; docile
sentences: The tractable puppy learned quickly.
She found the problem more tractable than expected.

words.definition: free from disturbance; calm and peaceful
sentences: The tranquil lake reflected the mountains.
We spent a tranquil afternoon in the garden.

words.definition: to rise above or go beyond the limits of
sentences: Her talent seemed to transcend normal limits.
The music transcended cultural boundaries.

words.definition: lasting only for a short time; temporary
sentences: The transient nature of fame troubled him.
They offered shelter to transient workers.

words.definition: not permanent; brief or fleeting
sentences: Youth is transitory and should be cherished.
The pain was transitory and soon faded.

words.definition: easy to perceive or detect; obvious
sentences: His lies were completely transparent.
The company promised transparent dealings.

words.definition: a false or distorted representation of something
sentences: The trial was a travesty of justice.
The movie was a travesty of the original book.

words.definition: a feeling of fear or anxiety about something
sentences: She approached the interview with trepidation.
He felt trepidation about the upcoming surgery.

words.definition: lacking originality or freshness; overused
sentences: The speech was full of trite expressions.
His trite advice was not helpful.

words.definition: of little value or importance; insignificant
sentences: They argued over trivial matters.
The error was trivial and easily fixed.

words.definition: eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressive
sentences: His truculent manner scared people away.
The truculent customer demanded a refund.

words.definition: to shorten by cutting off the top or end
sentences: The editor truncated the article for space.
The storm truncated our vacation plans.

words.definition: characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion
sentences: The country went through a turbulent period.
The turbulent waters made sailing difficult.

words.definition: swollen and distended; pompous or bombastic
sentences: The turgid prose was hard to read.
His turgid speech bored the audience.

words.definition: a state of great disturbance, confusion, or uncertainty
sentences: The company was in financial turmoil.
Political turmoil affected the whole region.

words.definition: cruel and oppressive government or rule
sentences: The people rose up against tyranny.
He escaped the tyranny of the dictator.

words.definition: perceptible by touch; clear and definite
sentences: There was no tangible evidence of wrongdoing.
She wanted tangible results from her efforts.

words.definition: to lose or cause to lose luster; to damage reputation
sentences: The scandal tarnished his reputation.
Silver can tarnish if not properly stored.

words.definition: showing moderation or self-restraint; mild climate
sentences: He maintained a temperate lifestyle.
The temperate climate was perfect for farming.

words.definition: relating to worldly rather than spiritual matters
sentences: He focused on temporal concerns rather than faith.
The temporal power of kings has declined.

words.definition: the quality of being persistent and determined
sentences: Her tenacity helped her overcome obstacles.
The team showed tenacity in the final quarter.

words.definition: the study of religious beliefs and theory
sentences: She studied theology at the university.
The debate touched on complex theology.

words.definition: a statement or theory put forward to be maintained or proved
sentences: Her thesis argued for educational reform.
The student defended his thesis successfully.

words.definition: complete with regard to every detail; not superficial
sentences: The investigation was thorough and complete.
She did a thorough job cleaning the house.

words.definition: worn thin; shabby or hackneyed
sentences: His threadbare excuses fooled no one.
The threadbare carpet needed replacement.

words.definition: using money and resources carefully; frugal
sentences: The thrifty shopper always found bargains.
Being thrifty helped her save for college.

words.definition: done or occurring at a favorable or appropriate time
sentences: His timely intervention saved the project.
The timely warning prevented disaster.

words.definition: causing one to feel bored or annoyed
sentences: His tiresome complaints annoyed everyone.
The tiresome journey seemed endless.

words.definition: serving as a symbolic representation of something
sentences: They made only token efforts to comply.
She received a token gift for her service.

words.definition: to allow the existence or occurrence of something without interference
sentences: She could not tolerate dishonesty.
The teacher tolerated no disruptions in class.

words.definition: a large, heavy book, especially one dealing with a scholarly subject
sentences: The professor carried a thick tome under his arm.
She spent years writing the historical tome.

words.definition: relating to current events or issues of interest
sentences: The documentary covered topical issues.
His topical humor resonated with the audience.

words.definition: a standard or criterion by which something is judged
sentences: Integrity was his touchstone for all decisions.
The album became a touchstone for the genre.

words.definition: poisonous; very harmful or unpleasant
sentences: The toxic chemicals polluted the river.
Their toxic relationship affected everyone around them.

words.definition: a custom or belief passed down through generations
sentences: They followed family tradition every holiday.
The tradition dates back centuries.

words.definition: the path followed by a moving object or person
sentences: The rocket followed its planned trajectory.
Her career trajectory was impressive.

words.definition: to transform into something more beautiful or elevated
sentences: The sunset transfigured the ordinary landscape.
Love seemed to transfigure her entire being.

words.definition: to violate a law, command, or moral code
sentences: He transgressed the rules of the organization.
Those who transgress will face consequences.

words.definition: to travel across or through
sentences: They traversed the mountain range on foot.
The expedition traversed uncharted territory.

words.definition: guilty of or involving betrayal or deception
sentences: The treacherous spy sold secrets to enemies.
The treacherous ice caused many accidents.

words.definition: a written work dealing formally with a subject
sentences: He published a treatise on political philosophy.
The scientific treatise was widely read.

words.definition: shaking or quivering slightly; timid or nervous
sentences: Her tremulous voice betrayed her fear.
He made a tremulous attempt at an apology.

words.definition: vigorous or incisive in expression or style
sentences: His trenchant criticism stung the author.
She offered a trenchant analysis of the problem.

words.definition: a thing of little value or importance
sentences: Don't waste time on such a trifle.
A trifle like that shouldn't upset you.

words.definition: overused and lacking freshness or originality
sentences: His trite expressions bored the audience.
The movie relied on trite plot devices.

words.definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere
sentences: Smartphones have become ubiquitous.
The company's logo was ubiquitous in the city.

words.definition: existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; hidden
sentences: She suspected he had ulterior motives.
His ulterior purpose soon became clear.

words.definition: offense or annoyance
sentences: He took umbrage at the casual insult.
She expressed umbrage at being overlooked.

words.definition: agreement by all people involved; consensus
sentences: The decision required complete unanimity.
There was unanimity among the board members.

words.definition: not pretentious or arrogant; modest
sentences: Despite his fame, he remained unassuming.
The unassuming restaurant served excellent food.

words.definition: not discouraged or intimidated by difficulty or danger
sentences: She remained undaunted by the challenges.
The undaunted explorer continued forward.

words.definition: to weaken or damage gradually
sentences: His comments undermined her confidence.
The scandal undermined public trust.

words.definition: to emphasize or stress the importance of
sentences: The report underscored the need for reform.
Her success underscored the value of persistence.

words.definition: to move with a smooth wavelike motion
sentences: The wheat fields undulated in the breeze.
Her dance movements undulated gracefully.

words.definition: leaving no doubt; unambiguous
sentences: Her answer was unequivocal.
The evidence was unequivocal proof of guilt.

words.definition: not confined or restricted
sentences: She enjoyed unfettered access to the archives.
The artist worked with unfettered creativity.

words.definition: remaining the same in all cases; consistent
sentences: The company enforced uniform standards.
The temperature remained uniform throughout.

words.definition: performed by or affecting only one side or party
sentences: The unilateral decision angered allies.
He made a unilateral choice without consulting others.

words.definition: never done or known before
sentences: The growth was unprecedented in company history.
They faced unprecedented challenges.

words.definition: not attempting to impress others with importance or wealth
sentences: The unpretentious cafe was cozy and welcoming.
She had an unpretentious charm about her.

words.definition: disorderly and disruptive; not amenable to discipline
sentences: The unruly crowd became difficult to manage.
His unruly hair refused to stay in place.

words.definition: not proper or appropriate
sentences: His unseemly behavior shocked the guests.
It would be unseemly to celebrate now.

words.definition: not able to be maintained or defended against criticism
sentences: His position became untenable after the revelations.
The theory was untenable given the evidence.

words.definition: not aware of the full facts; unintentional
sentences: He was an unwitting accomplice to the crime.

words.definition: to scold or criticize someone severely
sentences: The coach upbraided the player for laziness.
She upbraided him for his careless mistake.

words.definition: courteous and refined in manner
sentences: The urbane host made everyone feel welcome.
His urbane wit charmed the guests.

words.definition: to take a position of power illegally or by force
sentences: The general tried to usurp the throne.
She usurped control of the company.

words.definition: designed to be useful rather than attractive
sentences: The furniture was utilitarian but functional.

words.definition: an imagined place where everything is perfect
sentences: The novel described a technological utopia.

words.definition: complete or absolute
sentences: The project was an utter failure.
She stared in utter disbelief.

words.definition: not justified or authorized
sentences: The criticism was unwarranted and unfair.
His unwarranted interference caused problems.

words.definition: to maintain or support in the face of challenge
sentences: The court upheld the original decision.
She vowed to uphold the family tradition.

words.definition: a loud and impassioned noise or disturbance
sentences: The announcement caused an uproar.
The crowd was in an uproar after the call.

words.definition: a person who has risen suddenly to prominence
sentences: The upstart company challenged industry giants.

words.definition: the greatest or most extreme degree
sentences: She showed the utmost respect for elders.
It was of utmost importance to arrive on time.

words.definition: to alternate between different opinions or actions
sentences: He vacillated between two career paths.
She vacillated on the decision for weeks.

words.definition: having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence
sentences: His vacuous remarks added nothing to the debate.
The movie was criticized for its vacuous plot.

words.definition: having excessive pride in one's appearance or achievements
sentences: She was too vain to admit her mistakes.
His vain attempts to impress failed.

words.definition: to confirm the truth or value of something
sentences: The results validated her hypothesis.
He sought to validate his research findings.

words.definition: great courage in the face of danger
sentences: The soldier was decorated for valor.
She showed valor in defending her beliefs.

words.definition: to defeat thoroughly in battle or competition
sentences: The team vanquished their rivals.
They vanquished the invading army.

words.definition: offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging
sentences: The vapid conversation bored everyone.
Critics called the show vapid and pointless.

words.definition: showing strong feeling; forceful or passionate
sentences: She made a vehement denial of the charges.
His vehement protest surprised everyone.

words.definition: a superficial appearance meant to hide true nature
sentences: His politeness was just a veneer.
Beneath the veneer of success lay deep insecurity.

words.definition: accorded a great deal of respect due to age or wisdom
sentences: The venerable professor was highly respected.
They visited the venerable cathedral.

words.definition: to regard with great respect or reverence
sentences: The community venerates their ancestors.
She was venerated as a hero.

words.definition: speaking or representing the truth
sentences: He was known for being veracious.
The veracious account matched the evidence.

words.definition: conformity to facts; accuracy or truthfulness
sentences: The veracity of his claims was questioned.
She doubted the veracity of the report.

words.definition: using more words than needed; wordy
sentences: His verbose writing style tired readers.
The verbose explanation was hard to follow.

words.definition: green with grass or other rich vegetation
sentences: The verdant hills were beautiful in spring.
They walked through verdant meadows.

words.definition: to make sure or demonstrate that something is true
sentences: Please verify your email address.
The experiment was designed to verify the theory.

words.definition: the appearance of being true or real
sentences: The novel's verisimilitude made it compelling.
The film strived for historical verisimilitude.

words.definition: the language or dialect spoken by ordinary people
sentences: The book was written in the local vernacular.
He preferred to speak in the vernacular.

words.definition: able to adapt to many different functions or activities
sentences: She is a versatile musician.
The versatile tool had many uses.

words.definition: a trace or remnant of something that once existed
sentences: Only vestiges of the ancient city remain.
There was no vestige of doubt in her mind.

words.definition: to make someone feel annoyed or frustrated
sentences: The constant interruptions vexed her.
His evasive answers vexed the interviewer.

words.definition: capable of working successfully; feasible
sentences: Is this plan economically viable?
They searched for a viable alternative.

words.definition: experienced through the imagination or actions of another
sentences: She got vicarious pleasure from his success.

words.definition: keeping careful watch for possible danger
sentences: Security guards remained vigilant.
Parents should be vigilant about online safety.

words.definition: physical strength and good health; energy
sentences: He approached the task with renewed vigor.
The old man still had surprising vigor.

words.definition: to speak or write about in an abusively critical manner
sentences: The media vilified the politician.

words.definition: to clear of blame or suspicion
sentences: New evidence vindicated the accused.

words.definition: having a strong desire for revenge
sentences: Her vindictive nature made enemies.

words.definition: a person highly skilled in music or another art
sentences: The virtuoso performed brilliantly.

words.definition: extremely severe or harmful; bitterly hostile

words.definition: relating to deep inward feelings rather than intellect
sentences: She had a visceral reaction to the news.

words.definition: having a thick, sticky consistency between solid and liquid
sentences: The viscous liquid moved slowly.

words.definition: filled with bitter criticism or malice
sentences: His vitriolic comments hurt many people.

words.definition: to blame or insult someone in strong language
sentences: The critics vituperated the new policy.

words.definition: attractively lively and animated
sentences: Her vivacious personality lit up the room.

words.definition: a strong feeling of suitability for a particular career
sentences: Teaching was her true vocation.

words.definition: expressing opinions loudly and forcefully
sentences: The vociferous crowd demanded justice.

words.definition: liable to change rapidly and unpredictably
sentences: The stock market was extremely volatile.

words.definition: the faculty or power of using one's will
sentences: She left of her own volition.

words.definition: wanting or devouring great quantities of food or activity
sentences: He was a voracious reader.

words.definition: susceptible to physical or emotional harm
sentences: The system was vulnerable to attacks.

words.definition: to decrease in vigor, power, or extent

words.definition: deliberate and unprovoked; reckless
sentences: The wanton destruction shocked everyone.

words.definition: to justify or necessitate a certain action
sentences: The evidence did not warrant an arrest.

words.definition: feeling or showing caution about possible dangers
sentences: She was wary of strangers.

words.definition: to be undecided between two opinions or courses of action
sentences: He wavered between staying and leaving.
Her determination never wavered.

words.definition: playfully quaint or fanciful
sentences: The garden had a whimsical design.
Her whimsical stories delighted children.

words.definition: to hold and use a weapon or tool with control
sentences: He wielded the sword skillfully.

words.definition: intentional or deliberate; stubbornly determined
sentences: His willful neglect caused the accident.

words.definition: skilled at gaining an advantage through cunning
sentences: The wily fox escaped every trap.

words.definition: having a feeling of vague or regretful longing
sentences: She gave a wistful glance at the old house.

words.definition: to remain undamaged or unaffected by; resist

words.definition: shriveled or wrinkled with age
sentences: The wizened farmer told old stories.

words.definition: extreme anger; vengeance
sentences: She feared her father's wrath.

words.definition: using or expressing dry, mocking humor
sentences: He made a wry comment about the situation.

words.definition: to decrease gradually in size, amount, or intensity

words.definition: difficult to control or predict due to unusual behavior
sentences: The wayward child was always in trouble.

words.definition: on a large scale; extensive
sentences: The wholesale changes affected everyone.

words.definition: to make a slight involuntary grimace from pain or distress

words.definition: attractive or appealing in appearance or character
sentences: Her winsome smile won everyone over.

words.definition: not wanting to communicate with others; introverted

words.definition: to become dry and shriveled; to decline

words.definition: to argue or dispute noisily

words.definition: to cause a large amount of damage or harm

words.definition: to forcibly pull something from a person's grasp

words.definition: dislike or prejudice against people from other countries

words.definition: to have an intense feeling of longing for something
sentences: She yearned for her homeland.

words.definition: to give way to arguments, demands, or pressure
sentences: She refused to yield to pressure.

words.definition: a burden or bond that oppresses or constrains

words.definition: great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause

words.definition: having or showing zeal; enthusiastic

words.definition: the highest point or state; peak

words.definition: understood without being openly expressed

words.definition: to contaminate or pollute; corrupt

words.definition: a completely different line of thought or action

words.definition: delaying or delayed beyond the expected time; late

words.definition: stretched or pulled tight; tense

words.definition: showy but cheap and of poor quality

words.definition: showing little enthusiasm; lukewarm

words.definition: causing distress or difficulty; problematic

words.definition: easily managed or controlled

words.definition: fully in agreement

words.definition: uncontrolled; not restrained

words.definition: not able to be doubted, questioned, or criticized

words.definition: not conspicuous or attracting attention

words.definition: never done or known before

words.definition: not able to be maintained or defended

words.definition: difficult to carry or move because of size or shape

words.definition: strictly honorable or honest

words.definition: characterized by or provoking loud noise or laughter
sentences: The comedian gave an uproarious performance.
The party was uproarious and fun.

words.definition: the final or eventual outcome or conclusion
sentences: The upshot was that we had to start over.
What was the upshot of the meeting?

words.definition: the practice of lending money at unreasonably high interest
sentences: Laws were passed to prevent usury.
The practice of usury exploited the poor.

words.definition: an unexpected and inexplicable change in behavior
sentences: The vagaries of weather affected the crop.
His vagaries made him unpredictable.

words.definition: of uncertain or unclear character or meaning
sentences: His instructions were too vague to follow.
She had only a vague memory of the event.

words.definition: having a sound basis in logic or fact
sentences: Her concerns were perfectly valid.
Is this ticket still valid?

words.definition: excessive pride in one's appearance or achievements
sentences: His vanity prevented him from accepting help.
She kept a mirror to satisfy her vanity.

words.definition: a place or position affording a good view
sentences: From this vantage point, you can see everything.
The hill provided a good vantage.

words.definition: not consistent or having a fixed pattern; liable to change
sentences: The weather was highly variable.
Her moods were variable and unpredictable.

words.definition: to change direction suddenly
sentences: The car veered off the road.
The conversation veered to politics.

words.definition: to conceal or disguise
sentences: She veiled her disappointment with a smile.
Fog veiled the mountain peak.

words.definition: the speed of something in a given direction
sentences: The velocity of the wind increased.
The ball traveled at high velocity.

words.definition: a prolonged bitter quarrel or campaign against someone
sentences: He pursued a vendetta against his rival.
The family vendetta lasted for years.

words.definition: punishment inflicted in retaliation for injury
sentences: He sought vengeance for the wrong done to him.
The storm returned with a vengeance.

words.definition: to give free expression to an emotion
sentences: She vented her frustrations to a friend.
He needed to vent his anger.

words.definition: a risky or daring journey or undertaking
sentences: The business venture was successful.
They embarked on a new venture together.

words.definition: being truly or very much so; real
sentences: The garden was a veritable paradise.
She was a veritable expert on the topic.

words.definition: a constitutional right to reject a decision
sentences: The president exercised his veto.
Her mother had veto power over the decision.

words.definition: capable of working successfully; feasible
sentences: Is this a viable solution?
The plan was commercially viable.

words.definition: the area near or surrounding a particular place
sentences: There are shops in the vicinity.
The crime occurred in the vicinity of the park.

words.definition: to compete eagerly with someone to do or achieve something
sentences: The teams vied for first place.
Politicians vie for public attention.

words.definition: a period of staying awake to keep watch or pray
sentences: They held a candlelight vigil.
She kept vigil by his bedside.

words.definition: a brief evocative description or episode
sentences: The book contained charming vignettes of country life.
Each chapter was a vignette from history.

words.definition: energy and enthusiasm
sentences: She attacked the project with vim.
He was full of vim and vigor.

words.definition: of high quality from a past time
sentences: She collected vintage clothing.
The vintage car was beautifully restored.

words.definition: almost or nearly as described but not completely
sentences: The country was in a virtual state of war.
He was the virtual leader of the group.

words.definition: behavior showing high moral standards
sentences: Patience is a virtue.
She was a woman of great virtue.

words.definition: thinking about the future with imagination or wisdom
sentences: The visionary leader transformed the company.
Her visionary ideas were ahead of their time.

words.definition: the state of being strong and active; energy
sentences: She was bursting with vitality.
The city had a sense of vitality.

words.definition: producing powerful feelings or clear images in the mind
sentences: She had vivid memories of childhood.
The painting used vivid colors.

words.definition: the prevailing fashion or style at a particular time
sentences: Short skirts came back into vogue.
That style is no longer in vogue.

words.definition: completely empty; not valid or legally binding
sentences: The contract was declared void.
His life felt empty and void.

words.definition: speaking or spoken incessantly and fluently
sentences: The voluble host never stopped talking.
She became more voluble after a drink.

words.definition: to assert or confirm as true or accurate
sentences: I can vouch for her honesty.
He vouched for the quality of the work.

words.definition: to pass or cause to pass gently through the air
sentences: The smell of cookies wafted from the kitchen.
Music wafted through the open window.

words.definition: to refrain from insisting on or applying a right or claim
sentences: She waived her right to an attorney.
The fee was waived for new members.

words.definition: to indulge in an emotion or situation excessively
sentences: He wallowed in self-pity.
She refused to wallow in sadness.

words.definition: pale and giving the impression of illness or exhaustion
sentences: Her wan face showed her fatigue.
He gave a wan smile.

words.definition: to decrease in size or intensity
sentences: His enthusiasm began to wane.
The moon was waning.

words.definition: lacking in a certain quality; deficient
sentences: His performance was found wanting.
The proposal was wanting in detail.

words.definition: to sing in a trilling or quavering voice
sentences: Birds warbled in the trees.
She warbled a tune while working.

words.definition: a person responsible for supervision or enforcement
sentences: The game warden patrolled the forest.
The prison warden was strict but fair.

words.definition: to make or become bent or twisted out of shape
sentences: The heat warped the wooden door.
His judgment was warped by jealousy.

words.definition: an event marking a turning point in a course of action
sentences: The election was a watershed moment.
The discovery was a watershed in medicine.

words.definition: to grow larger or stronger; to increase
sentences: The moon waxed and waned.
His confidence waxed as he practiced.

words.definition: feeling or showing tiredness
sentences: The weary travelers rested by the road.
She was weary of his excuses.

words.definition: to withstand or come safely through a difficult situation
sentences: The company weathered the recession.
They weathered many storms together.

words.definition: to sharpen or stimulate interest or appetite
sentences: The preview whetted her appetite for the movie.
He whetted the blade on a stone.

words.definition: to become limp or lose freshness; to lose energy
sentences: The flowers wilted in the heat.
Her enthusiasm began to wilt.

words.definition: an unexpected piece of good fortune or gain
sentences: The inheritance was a financial windfall.
The company enjoyed a windfall profit.

words.definition: to reduce by removing unwanted elements
sentences: They winnowed the list of candidates.
The editor winnowed the manuscript.

words.definition: having a feeling of vague longing
sentences: She cast a wistful glance at the old house.
His wistful tone revealed his nostalgia.

words.definition: mental sharpness and inventiveness; keen intelligence
sentences: Her wit made her popular at parties.
He relied on his wit to survive.

words.definition: great sorrow or distress
sentences: She shared her woes with a friend.
The country experienced great woe.

words.definition: experienced and sophisticated; related to material things
sentences: He gave up worldly possessions.
She was a worldly and cultured woman.

words.definition: to show reverence and adoration for a deity or person
sentences: They gathered to worship together.
He worshipped his older brother.

words.definition: to argue or dispute angrily
sentences: They wrangled over the terms of the contract.
The siblings wrangled constantly.

words.definition: a form of written command in the name of authority
sentences: The court issued a writ.
His authority ran writ large across the land.

words.definition: to make twisting movements from pain or struggle
sentences: He writhed in agony on the ground.
The worm writhed when touched.
